introduction: In~\cite{GH}, Gerard {}'t Hooft sought an analytic continuation of the fractional polylogarithm \begin{equation} G(z)=\sum_{n>0}\sqrt{n}z^n,\text{ for } |z|<1\label{Gz} \end{equation} to values with $|z|\ge1$, excluding a branch-cut with $z\in[1,\,\infty)$. A solution to this problem is well-known~\cite{OC,DW}, namely \begin{equation} G(z)=\frac{\sqrt{\pi}}{2}\sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty}\left(\frac{1}{2n\pi{\rm i}-\log(z)}\right)^{3/2}, \text{ for }z\notin[1,\infty).\label{Gsum} \end{equation} Section~2 reviews computational strategies for $G(z)$. Section~3 considers its behaviour on the negative axis where $G(-e^u)$, at large positive $u$, is given by optimal truncation of a sign-constant asymptotic expansion in $1/u^2$, leaving an exponentially suppressed term $e^{-u}S(u)$. Then the asymptotic expansion of $S(u)\sim\sum_{k\ge0}P_k(x)/u^k$ yields a remarkable sequence of polynomials, $P_k(x)$, with argument $x=u/2-\lfloor u/2\rfloor$. In Section~4, I conjecture formula~(\ref{Pkasy}), for $P_k(x)$ at large $k$ with $x\in[0,1)$, and give 100-digit values for the unidentified asymptotic constants, $C$ and $R$, that it involves. Section~5 provides a discussion and some open questions.

sections.title: Introduction
sections.content: In~\cite{GH}, Gerard {}'t Hooft sought an analytic continuation of the fractional polylogarithm \begin{equation} G(z)=\sum_{n>0}\sqrt{n}z^n,\text{ for } |z|<1\label{Gz} \end{equation} to values with $|z|\ge1$, excluding a branch-cut with $z\in[1,\,\infty)$. A solution to this problem is well-known~\cite{OC,DW}, namely \begin{equation} G(z)=\frac{\sqrt{\pi}}{2}\sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty}\left(\frac{1}{2n\pi{\rm i}-\log(z)}\right)^{3/2}, \text{ for }z\notin[1,\infty).\label{Gsum} \end{equation} Section~2 reviews computational strategies for $G(z)$. Section~3 considers its behaviour on the negative axis where $G(-e^u)$, at large positive $u$, is given by optimal truncation of a sign-constant asymptotic expansion in $1/u^2$, leaving an exponentially suppressed term $e^{-u}S(u)$. Then the asymptotic expansion of $S(u)\sim\sum_{k\ge0}P_k(x)/u^k$ yields a remarkable sequence of polynomials, $P_k(x)$, with argument $x=u/2-\lfloor u/2\rfloor$. In Section~4, I conjecture formula~(\ref{Pkasy}), for $P_k(x)$ at large $k$ with $x\in[0,1)$, and give 100-digit values for the unidentified asymptotic constants, $C$ and $R$, that it involves. Section~5 provides a discussion and some open questions.

sections.title: Computation of a fractional polylogarithm
sections.content: In an informative report~\cite{DW} on computation of polylogarithms, David C.\ Woods gave formulas for the analytic continuation of a polylogarithm with ${\rm Li}_p(z)=\sum_{n>0}z^n/n^p$ for $|z|<1$. One obtains~(\ref{Gsum}) for $G(z)$ with $p=-\frac12$ as a particular case of~\cite[Eq.\ 13.1]{DW}. I define $\log(z)$ on in its first sheet, with $\Im(\log(z))\in(-\pi,\pi]$. Then the discontinuity of $\log(z)$ across its branch-cut on the negative real $z$-axis causes no problem, since any integer multiple of $2\pi{\rm i}$ is absorbed by shifting $n$ by an integer in the bilateral sum~(\ref{Gsum}). For real $z\ge1$, the term with $n=0$ in~(\ref{Gsum}) creates a branch-cut. I assume that $z\notin[1,\,\infty)$. Then~(\ref{Gsum}) has the complex-conjugation property $\overline{G(z)}=G(\overline{z})$ that was requested by {}'t Hooft in~\cite[Section 3]{GH}. One may efficiently compute $G(z)$ for $\frac12<|z|<20<e^{\pi}$, using \begin{gather} G(z)=\frac{\sqrt{\pi}}{2(-\log(z))^{3/2}}+\sum_{n\ge0}\zeta(-n-\tfrac12)\frac{(\log(z))^n}{n!}, \text{ for }|\log(z)|<2\pi\label{Gzeta}\\ \zeta(-n-\tfrac12)=-2\sin\left(\tfrac14(2n+1)\pi\right)\Gamma(n+\tfrac32)\zeta(n+\tfrac32)/(2\pi)^{n+3/2}\label{zeta} \end{gather} where~(\ref{Gzeta}) is obtained from~\cite[Eq.\ 9.3]{DW} and~(\ref{zeta}) from analytic continuation of the Riemann zeta function, defined by $\zeta(s)=\sum_{n>0}n^{-s}$ for $\Re s>1$. For $|z|>20$, it is preferable to use the inversion formula \begin{equation} G(z)={\rm i}\,G(1/z)+\frac{{\rm i}-1}{4\pi}\sum_{n\ge0}\left(n+\frac{\log(z)}{2\pi{\rm i}}\right)^{-3/2}, \text{ for }|z|\ge1\text{ and }\Im z\ge0\label{Ginv} \end{equation} which is obtained from~\cite[Eq.\ 10.4]{DW} and gives the neat evaluation \begin{equation} G(-1)=\frac{(1-2\sqrt2)\,\zeta(\frac32)}{4\pi}=-0.3801048126\ldots\label{Gm1} \end{equation} With $|z|>20$ in~(\ref{Ginv}), the first term on the right is quickly evaluated by~(\ref{Gz}) and in the second term one encounters a complex Hurwitz zeta value, for which there is an efficient Euler-MacLaurin procedure~\cite{FJ}. Most intriguingly, Woods gives an asymptotic expansion for ${\rm Li}_p(z)$ on the negative $z$-axis, with $z\ll-1$. Setting $z=-e^{u}$, with large positive $u$, and substituting $p=-\frac12$ in~\cite[Eq.\ 11.1]{DW}, one obtains the optimally truncated estimate \begin{equation} G(-e^u)=-\frac{2}{\pi\sqrt{u}}\sum_{n=0}^{\lfloor u/2\rfloor}\eta(2n)\Gamma(2n+\tfrac12)u^{-2n}+O(e^{-u})\label{Gu} \end{equation} where $\eta(s)=(1-2^{1-s})\zeta(s)$ and hence $\eta(0)=\frac12$.

sections.title: A remarkable sequence of polynomials
sections.content: For real $u\ge0$, it follows from~(\ref{Ginv}) that \begin{equation} G(-e^u)=\Re\left[\frac{{\rm i}-1}{4\pi}\sum_{n\ge0}\left(n+\frac12+\frac{u}{2\pi{\rm i}}\right)^{-3/2}\right]\label{Gh} \end{equation} is determined by a complex Hurwitz zeta value. From~(\ref{Gu}), it follows that for large $u$ one may express $G(-e^u)$ in terms of an optimally truncated sign-constant asymptotic expansion in $1/u^2$, together with an exponentially suppressed term. For $u>0$, I define $S(u)$ by the Ansatz \begin{equation} G(-e^u)=-\frac{2}{\pi\sqrt{u}}\left[\sum_{n=0}^{\lfloor u/2\rfloor}\eta(2n)\Gamma(2n+\tfrac12)u^{-2n} +\sqrt{2\pi}\,e^{-u}S(u)\right].\label{Ga} \end{equation} From numerical computation of~(\ref{Gh}), I found that $S(u)\in(-0.7,\,0.4)$, for $u>0$, and that $S(u)=x-\frac23+O(1/u)$, for large $u$, with $x=u/2-\lfloor u/2\rfloor$. Moreover, I found that this is the first term of an asymptotic series, of the form \begin{equation} S(u)=\sum_{k=0}^{\lfloor u\rfloor}\frac{P_k(x)}{u^k}+O(e^{-u}),\quad x=\frac{u}{2}-\left\lfloor\frac{u}{2}\right\rfloor\in[0,1)\label{Sa} \end{equation} where $P_k(x)$ is a polynomial of degree $2k+1$ with rational coefficients. The sequence of polynomials begins with \begin{align} P_0(x)&=x -\tfrac23\label{P0}\\ P_1(x)&=\tfrac23x^3 - x^2 + \tfrac{7}{24}x + \tfrac{47}{2160}\label{P01}\\ P_2(x)&=\tfrac25x^5 - \tfrac23x^4 - \tfrac{1}{36}x^3 + \tfrac13x^2 - \tfrac{73}{1920}x - \tfrac{433}{24192}\label{P2}\\ P_3(x)&=\tfrac{4}{21}x^7 - \tfrac29x^6 - \tfrac{5}{12}x^5 + \tfrac{31}{72}x^4 + \tfrac{433}{1728}x^3 - \tfrac{223}{1152}x^2 - \tfrac{106619}{2903040}x + \tfrac{28583}{2488320}\label{P3} \end{align} and has been developed up to $k=166$. Denominators of the coefficients of $P_k(x)$ contain no prime greater than $2k+3$. The differences $\Delta_k(x)=P_k(x+1)-P_k(x)$ are determined by the asymptotic series \begin{equation} \frac{e^u}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\,\frac{\Gamma(u-2x+\tfrac12)}{u^{u-2x}}\,\sim\,\sum_{k\ge0}\frac{\Delta_k(x)}{u^k} =1+\frac{2x^2 - \tfrac{1}{24}}{u}+O\left(\frac{1}{u^2}\right)\label{dexp} \end{equation} since the transformation $x\to x+1$ would correspond to the instruction to omit the last term of the summation in~(\ref{Ga}), at $n=\frac12u-x$. Taking a logarithm, I obtain \begin{equation} \log\left[\sum_{k\ge0}\frac{\Delta_k(x)}{u^k}\right]\,\sim\,t+(u+\tfrac12-t)\log\left(1-\frac{t}{u}\right) +\sum_{n>0}\frac{B_{2n}}{2n(2n-1)}\left(\frac{1}{u-t}\right)^{2n-1}\label{dlog} \end{equation} where $t=2x+\frac12$ and $B_{2n}$ is a Bernoulli number. \newpage The finite difference equation $P_k(x+1)=P_k(x)+\Delta_k(x)$ determines the polynomial $P_k(x)$ modulo its constant term, $P_k(0)$. To determine $P_k(0)$, I resorted to experiment, using {\tt zetahurwitz} in {\tt Pari/GP}~\cite{Pari} to compute instances of $G(-e^u)$ at 600 even integers, $u_n\in[6002,\,7200]$, working at 6000-digit precision. This took 30 minutes on a single core. Then~(\ref{Ga}) gives sufficient precision to determine, iteratively, 167 rational values of $P_k(0)$ from 600 expansions $S(u_n)\approx\sum_{k\ge0}^{166}P_k(0)/u_n^k$. The iterative process relies on control of the denominator $D_k$ of $P_k(0)=N_k/D_k$. I found that $D_k/D_{k-1}$ is a relatively small rational number, involving no prime greater than $2k+3$. For example $D_{166}/D_{165}=2^3\cdot3^3\cdot5\cdot11\cdot113=1342440$, while $N_{166}$ is 780-digit integer, obtained from numerical data with an absolute error less than $10^{-27}$ and hence with good confidence. Combining this empirical data for $P_k(0)$ with difference polynomials $\Delta_k(x)$, obtained by rational linear algebra from~(\ref{dlog}), I determined $P_k(x)$ exactly for $k\in[0,166]$. Studying these results I found that $P_k(x)$ at large $k$ is very well approximated by a sinusoid whose amplitude grows with $k$ exponentially faster than that for $\Delta_k(x)$. Moreover, the phase of this sinusoid for $P_k(x)$ increases linearly with $k$. From~(\ref{dlog}), one sees that $g_k=\Delta_k(-\frac14)$ has the well-studied generating function~\cite{RA,GN} \begin{equation} \sum_{k\ge0}g_ky^k=\exp\left(\sum_{n>0}\frac{B_{2n}\,y^{2n-1}}{2n(2n-1)}\right)= 1+\tfrac{1}{12}y+\tfrac{1}{288}y^2-\tfrac{139}{51840}y^3-\tfrac{571}{2488320}y^4 +O(y^5).\label{gfun} \end{equation} At large $k$, one has $kg_k=O(k!/(2\pi)^k)$. The detailed behaviour depends on the parity of $k$, with resurgent asymptotic expansions given by \begin{equation} g_{2m}\sim-2\sum_{n=0}^{\lfloor m/2\rfloor}\frac{\Gamma(2m-2n-1)g_{2n+1}}{(2\pi{\rm i})^{2m-2n}},\quad g_{2m-1}\sim-2\sum_{n=0}^{\lfloor m/2\rfloor}\frac{\Gamma(2m-2n-1)g_{2n}}{(2\pi{\rm i})^{2m-2n}}\label{gres} \end{equation} optimally truncated at $n=\lfloor m/2\rfloor$. I found that \begin{equation}\Delta_k(x)=\frac{2\,\Gamma(k)}{(2\pi)^{k+1}}\left(\sin\left(4\pi x-\frac{k\pi}{2}\right) +O\left(\frac{1}{k}\right)\right)\label{Dkasy} \end{equation} for large $k$ and $x\in(-1,\,1)$. At $x=-\frac14$, this accords with the leading terms in~(\ref{gres}). Solving the difference equation $P_k(x+1)=P_k(x)+\Delta_k(x)$, with the boundary value $P_k(0)$ determined from fits to Hurwitz zeta values, I found a very different sinusoidal pattern for $P_k(x)$ at large $k$.

sections.title: Asymptotic constants
sections.content: {\bf Conjecture 1:} {\em For $x\in[0,1)$ and large $k$, there are real constants $(C,R)$ such that} \begin{equation} P_k(x)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\left(\sin((2k+1)C-2\pi x) +O\left(\frac{1}{(2\pi R^2)^k}\right)\right)R^{2k+1}\Gamma(k+\tfrac12).\label{Pkasy} \end{equation} I obtained from $P_k(x)$ with $k\le100$ the approximate values \begin{equation} C\approx1.0688539158679530121571,\quad R\approx0.5181839789815558726739.\label{RC} \end{equation} The correction to the sinusoid in~(\ref{Pkasy}) is suppressed by a factor $\exp(-Dk)$, with $D=\log(2\pi R^2)>0.523$, while $C$ determines the rate at which the phase of $P_k(x)$ increases with $k$. The frequency of the sinusoid in the accurate formula for $P_k(x)$ at large $k$ is half the frequency of the rough approximation of $\Delta_k(x)$ in~(\ref{Dkasy}). Remarkably, one does not need to evaluate more Hurwitz zeta values to improve the estimates for $C$ and $R$, since the derivatives $P_k^\prime(0)$ and $P_k^{\prime\prime}(0)$ suffice for this purpose. These are determined by $\Delta_k(z)=P_k(x+1)-P_k(x)$, using rational linear algebra. Performing this algebraic task up to $k=450$, I obtained 100 good digits of\begin{verbatim} C=1.0688539158679530121571097191811852979525324693901\ 17623122615884099900607451406841033559634662009219352... R=0.5181839789815558726739156977092964730544254253791\ 86245211522277584117542967758199301076306776194323459... \end{verbatim}

sections.title: Discussion and open questions
sections.content: I have been unable to discover any relation between $C$, $R$, their square roots, powers, logarithms or exponentials, and guesses such as 2, 3, $\pi$, and their square roots, powers, logarithms or exponentials. It might be more appropriate to consider a complex constant, such as $\log(R)+{\rm i}\,C$, or perhaps $R+{\rm i}\exp(C)$. Since determination of the derivatives $P_k^\prime(0)$ and $P_k^{\prime\prime}(0)$ from the finite difference equation $P_k(x+1)-P_k(x)=\Delta_k(x)$, at large $k$, is somewhat akin to integration, it might be that $C$ and $R$ are related to the real and imaginary parts of a complex integral, or come from the saddle-point of a complex integrand. It is notable that the overall constant $1/\sqrt{2\pi}$ in~(\ref{Pkasy}) is very simple. One often encounters growth of the form $A\,r^k\,\Gamma(k+c)$, where $r$ is easily identified and $c$ is often a simple rational number, yet the overall constant $A$ may be hard to identify, as for example in~\cite{BB}. In the present case I cannot identify $R$, yet can confirm the overall constant $1/\sqrt{2\pi}$, at 100-digit precision. I conclude with several open questions. \begin{enumerate} \item May the rational numbers $P_k(0)$ be determined without recourse to numerical evaluation of Hurwitz zeta values? \item Can formula~(\ref{Pkasy}) of Conjecture~1 be proved? \item Might some function of $C$ and/or $R$ be determined precisely? \item Is the sign-constant asymptotic expansion~(\ref{Gu}) better handled using directional Borel resummation, as in~\cite{DD}, instead of optimal truncation, as here? \end{enumerate}

sections.title: Acknowledgments
sections.content: I am grateful for discussions with David Gross and Gerard {}'t Hooft, at {\em Bohr-100: Current Themes in Theoretical Physics}, held at the Niels Bohr Institute, in 2022, and with Ovidiu Costin, Daniele Dorigoni and Gerald Dunne, at {\em Resurgence and Modularity in QFT and String Theory}, held at the Galileo Galilei Institute, in 2024. }\raggedright \begin{thebibliography}{9} \bibitem{RA} Richard A.\ Askey and Ranjan Roy, Gamma function, {\em NIST Digital Library of Mathematical Functions}, Chapter 5, \url{https://dlmf.nist.gov/5.11} \bibitem{BB} Michael Borinsky and David Broadhurst, Resonant resurgent asymptotics from quantum field theory, Nucl.\ Phys.\ {\bf B20} (2022) 115861, \url{https://arxiv.org/abs/2202.01513} \bibitem{DD} David Broadhurst and Daniele Dorigoni, Resurgent Lambert series with characters, \url{https://arxiv.org/abs/2507.21352} \bibitem{OC} Ovidiu Costin and Stavros Garoufalidis, Resurgence of the fractional polylogarithms, Math.\ Res.\ Lett.\ {\bf 16} (2009) 817--826, \url{https://arxiv.org/abs/math/0701743} \bibitem{GH} Gerard {}'t Hooft, The hidden ontological variable in quantum harmonic oscillators, Front.\ Quantum Sci.\ Technol.\ {\bf 3} (2024) 1505593, \url{https://arxiv.org/abs/2407.18153} \bibitem{FJ} Fredrik Johansson, Rigorous high-precision computation of the Hurwitz zeta function and its derivatives, Numer.\ Algor.\ {\bf 69} (2015) 253--270, \url{https://arxiv.org/abs/1309.2877} \bibitem{GN} Gerg\H{o} Nemes, Error bounds and exponential improvements for the asymptotic expansions of the gamma function and its reciprocal, Proc.\ Roy.\ Soc.\ Edinburgh, {\bf A145} (2015) 571--596, \url{https://arxiv.org/abs/1310.0166} \bibitem{Pari} The PARI~Group, University of Bordeaux, {\tt Pari/GP} version {\tt 2.17.2} (2025), \url{http://pari.math.u-bordeaux.fr} \bibitem{DW} David C.\ Woods, The computation of polylogarithms, Technical Report 15-92, University of Kent (1992), \url{https://www.cs.kent.ac.uk/pubs/1992/110/content.pdf} \end{thebibliography} \end{document}

references: \begin{thebibliography}{9} \bibitem{RA} Richard A.\ Askey and Ranjan Roy, Gamma function, {\em NIST Digital Library of Mathematical Functions}, Chapter 5, \url{https://dlmf.nist.gov/5.11} \bibitem{BB} Michael Borinsky and David Broadhurst, Resonant resurgent asymptotics from quantum field theory, Nucl.\ Phys.\ {\bf B20} (2022) 115861, \url{https://arxiv.org/abs/2202.01513} \bibitem{DD} David Broadhurst and Daniele Dorigoni, Resurgent Lambert series with characters, \url{https://arxiv.org/abs/2507.21352} \bibitem{OC} Ovidiu Costin and Stavros Garoufalidis, Resurgence of the fractional polylogarithms, Math.\ Res.\ Lett.\ {\bf 16} (2009) 817--826, \url{https://arxiv.org/abs/math/0701743} \bibitem{GH} Gerard {}'t Hooft, The hidden ontological variable in quantum harmonic oscillators, Front.\ Quantum Sci.\ Technol.\ {\bf 3} (2024) 1505593, \url{https://arxiv.org/abs/2407.18153} \bibitem{FJ} Fredrik Johansson, Rigorous high-precision computation of the Hurwitz zeta function and its derivatives, Numer.\ Algor.\ {\bf 69} (2015) 253--270, \url{https://arxiv.org/abs/1309.2877} \bibitem{GN} Gerg\H{o} Nemes, Error bounds and exponential improvements for the asymptotic expansions of the gamma function and its reciprocal, Proc.\ Roy.\ Soc.\ Edinburgh, {\bf A145} (2015) 571--596, \url{https://arxiv.org/abs/1310.0166} \bibitem{Pari} The PARI~Group, University of Bordeaux, {\tt Pari/GP} version {\tt 2.17.2} (2025), \url{http://pari.math.u-bordeaux.fr} \bibitem{DW} David C.\ Woods, The computation of polylogarithms, Technical Report 15-92, University of Kent (1992), \url{https://www.cs.kent.ac.uk/pubs/1992/110/content.pdf} \end{thebibliography}
full_content:
\documentclass[12pt]{article} \usepackage{amsmath,amssymb,url} \usepackage[none]{hyphenat} 	extwidth 180 mm 	extheight 250mm \hoffset -25mm \voffset -17mm \setlength{	opmargin}{-10mm} \setlength{\parskip}{2mm} \setlength{\parindent}{0mm}  egin{document}  egin{center}{\huge f Polynomials and asymptotic constants\[2pt] in a resurgent problem from {}'t Hooft}\[4pt] {\Large David Broadhurst, Open University, UK, 30 September 2025}\end{center} {\large{ f Abstract:} In a recent study of the quantum theory of harmonic oscillators, Gerard {}'t Hooft proposed the following problem: given $G(z)=\sum_{n>0}\sqrt{n}z^n$ for $|z|<1$, find its analytic continuation for $|z|\ge1$, excluding a branch-cut $z\in[1,\,\infty)$. A solution is provided by the bilateral convergent sum $G(z)= rac12\sqrt{\pi}\sum_{n\in{\mathbb Z}}(2n\pi{m i}-\log(z))^{-3/2}$. On the negative real axis, $G(-e^u)$ has a sign-constant asymptotic expansion in $1/u^2$, for large positive $u$. Optimal truncation leaves exponentially suppressed terms in an asymptotic expansion $e^{-u}\sum_{k\ge0}P_k(x)/u^k$, with $P_0(x)=x- rac23$ and $P_k(x)$ of degree $2k+1$ evaluated at $x=u/2-\lfloor u/2floor$. These polynomials become excellent approximations to sinusoids. The amplitude of $P_k(x)$ increases factorially with $k$ and its phase increases linearly, with $P_k(x)\sim\sin((2k+1)C-2\pi x) R^{2k+1}\Gamma(k+ rac12)/\sqrt{2\pi}$,\ where $C\approx1.0688539158679530121571$ and $R\approx0.5181839789815558726739$ are asymptotic constants that have been determined at 100-digit precision. Their exact values remain to be identified. This work combines results from David C.\ Woods, on fractional polylogarithms, with evaluations of Hurwitz zeta values by {	t Pari/GP}. \section{Introduction} In~\cite{GH}, Gerard {}'t Hooft sought an analytic continuation of the fractional polylogarithm  egin{equation} G(z)=\sum_{n>0}\sqrt{n}z^n,	ext{ for } |z|<1\label{Gz} \end{equation} to values with $|z|\ge1$, excluding a branch-cut with $z\in[1,\,\infty)$. A solution to this problem is well-known~\cite{OC,DW}, namely  egin{equation} G(z)= rac{\sqrt{\pi}}{2}\sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty}\left( rac{1}{2n\pi{m i}-\log(z)}ight)^{3/2}, 	ext{ for }z
otin[1,\infty).\label{Gsum} \end{equation} Section~2 reviews computational strategies for $G(z)$. Section~3 considers its behaviour on the negative axis where $G(-e^u)$, at large positive $u$, is given by optimal truncation of a sign-constant asymptotic expansion in $1/u^2$, leaving an exponentially suppressed term $e^{-u}S(u)$. Then the asymptotic expansion of $S(u)\sim\sum_{k\ge0}P_k(x)/u^k$ yields a remarkable sequence of polynomials, $P_k(x)$, with argument $x=u/2-\lfloor u/2floor$. In Section~4, I conjecture formula~(ef{Pkasy}), for $P_k(x)$ at large $k$ with $x\in[0,1)$, and give 100-digit values for the unidentified asymptotic constants, $C$ and $R$, that it involves. Section~5 provides a discussion and some open questions. \section{Computation of a fractional polylogarithm} In an informative report~\cite{DW} on computation of polylogarithms, David C.\ Woods gave formulas for the analytic continuation of a polylogarithm with ${m Li}_p(z)=\sum_{n>0}z^n/n^p$ for $|z|<1$. One obtains~(ef{Gsum}) for $G(z)$ with $p=- rac12$ as a particular case of~\cite[Eq.\ 13.1]{DW}. I define $\log(z)$ on in its first sheet, with $\Im(\log(z))\in(-\pi,\pi]$. Then the discontinuity of $\log(z)$ across its branch-cut on the negative real $z$-axis causes no problem, since any integer multiple of $2\pi{m i}$ is absorbed by shifting $n$ by an integer in the bilateral sum~(ef{Gsum}). For real $z\ge1$, the term with $n=0$ in~(ef{Gsum}) creates a branch-cut. I assume that $z
otin[1,\,\infty)$. Then~(ef{Gsum}) has the complex-conjugation property $\overline{G(z)}=G(\overline{z})$ that was requested by {}'t Hooft in~\cite[Section 3]{GH}. One may efficiently compute $G(z)$ for $ rac12<|z|<20<e^{\pi}$, using  egin{gather} G(z)= rac{\sqrt{\pi}}{2(-\log(z))^{3/2}}+\sum_{n\ge0}\zeta(-n-	frac12) rac{(\log(z))^n}{n!}, 	ext{ for }|\log(z)|<2\pi\label{Gzeta}\ \zeta(-n-	frac12)=-2\sin\left(	frac14(2n+1)\piight)\Gamma(n+	frac32)\zeta(n+	frac32)/(2\pi)^{n+3/2}\label{zeta} \end{gather} where~(ef{Gzeta}) is obtained from~\cite[Eq.\ 9.3]{DW} and~(ef{zeta}) from analytic continuation of the Riemann zeta function, defined by $\zeta(s)=\sum_{n>0}n^{-s}$ for $\Re s>1$. For $|z|>20$, it is preferable to use the inversion formula  egin{equation} G(z)={m i}\,G(1/z)+ rac{{m i}-1}{4\pi}\sum_{n\ge0}\left(n+ rac{\log(z)}{2\pi{m i}}ight)^{-3/2}, 	ext{ for }|z|\ge1	ext{ and }\Im z\ge0\label{Ginv} \end{equation} which is obtained from~\cite[Eq.\ 10.4]{DW} and gives the neat evaluation  egin{equation} G(-1)= rac{(1-2\sqrt2)\,\zeta( rac32)}{4\pi}=-0.3801048126\ldots\label{Gm1} \end{equation} With $|z|>20$ in~(ef{Ginv}), the first term on the right is quickly evaluated by~(ef{Gz}) and in the second term one encounters a complex Hurwitz zeta value, for which there is an efficient Euler-MacLaurin procedure~\cite{FJ}. Most intriguingly, Woods gives an asymptotic expansion for ${m Li}_p(z)$ on the negative $z$-axis, with $z\ll-1$. Setting $z=-e^{u}$, with large positive $u$, and substituting $p=- rac12$ in~\cite[Eq.\ 11.1]{DW}, one obtains the optimally truncated estimate  egin{equation} G(-e^u)=- rac{2}{\pi\sqrt{u}}\sum_{n=0}^{\lfloor u/2floor}\eta(2n)\Gamma(2n+	frac12)u^{-2n}+O(e^{-u})\label{Gu} \end{equation} where $\eta(s)=(1-2^{1-s})\zeta(s)$ and hence $\eta(0)= rac12$. \section{A remarkable sequence of polynomials} For real $u\ge0$, it follows from~(ef{Ginv}) that  egin{equation} G(-e^u)=\Re\left[ rac{{m i}-1}{4\pi}\sum_{n\ge0}\left(n+ rac12+ rac{u}{2\pi{m i}}ight)^{-3/2}ight]\label{Gh} \end{equation} is determined by a complex Hurwitz zeta value. From~(ef{Gu}), it follows that for large $u$ one may express $G(-e^u)$ in terms of an optimally truncated sign-constant asymptotic expansion in $1/u^2$, together with an exponentially suppressed term. For $u>0$, I define $S(u)$ by the Ansatz  egin{equation} G(-e^u)=- rac{2}{\pi\sqrt{u}}\left[\sum_{n=0}^{\lfloor u/2floor}\eta(2n)\Gamma(2n+	frac12)u^{-2n} +\sqrt{2\pi}\,e^{-u}S(u)ight].\label{Ga} \end{equation} From numerical computation of~(ef{Gh}), I found that $S(u)\in(-0.7,\,0.4)$, for $u>0$, and that $S(u)=x- rac23+O(1/u)$, for large $u$, with $x=u/2-\lfloor u/2floor$. Moreover, I found that this is the first term of an asymptotic series, of the form  egin{equation} S(u)=\sum_{k=0}^{\lfloor ufloor} rac{P_k(x)}{u^k}+O(e^{-u}),\quad x= rac{u}{2}-\left\lfloor rac{u}{2}ightfloor\in[0,1)\label{Sa} \end{equation} where $P_k(x)$ is a polynomial of degree $2k+1$ with rational coefficients. The sequence of polynomials begins with  egin{align} P_0(x)&=x -	frac23\label{P0}\ P_1(x)&=	frac23x^3 - x^2 + 	frac{7}{24}x + 	frac{47}{2160}\label{P01}\ P_2(x)&=	frac25x^5 - 	frac23x^4 - 	frac{1}{36}x^3 + 	frac13x^2 - 	frac{73}{1920}x - 	frac{433}{24192}\label{P2}\ P_3(x)&=	frac{4}{21}x^7 - 	frac29x^6 - 	frac{5}{12}x^5 + 	frac{31}{72}x^4 + 	frac{433}{1728}x^3 - 	frac{223}{1152}x^2 - 	frac{106619}{2903040}x + 	frac{28583}{2488320}\label{P3} \end{align} and has been developed up to $k=166$. Denominators of the coefficients of $P_k(x)$ contain no prime greater than $2k+3$. The differences $\Delta_k(x)=P_k(x+1)-P_k(x)$ are determined by the asymptotic series  egin{equation}  rac{e^u}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\, rac{\Gamma(u-2x+	frac12)}{u^{u-2x}}\,\sim\,\sum_{k\ge0} rac{\Delta_k(x)}{u^k} =1+ rac{2x^2 - 	frac{1}{24}}{u}+O\left( rac{1}{u^2}ight)\label{dexp} \end{equation} since the transformation $x	o x+1$ would correspond to the instruction to omit the last term of the summation in~(ef{Ga}), at $n= rac12u-x$. Taking a logarithm, I obtain  egin{equation} \log\left[\sum_{k\ge0} rac{\Delta_k(x)}{u^k}ight]\,\sim\,t+(u+	frac12-t)\log\left(1- rac{t}{u}ight) +\sum_{n>0} rac{B_{2n}}{2n(2n-1)}\left( rac{1}{u-t}ight)^{2n-1}\label{dlog} \end{equation} where $t=2x+ rac12$ and $B_{2n}$ is a Bernoulli number. 
ewpage The finite difference equation $P_k(x+1)=P_k(x)+\Delta_k(x)$ determines the polynomial $P_k(x)$ modulo its constant term, $P_k(0)$. To determine $P_k(0)$, I resorted to experiment, using {	t zetahurwitz} in {	t Pari/GP}~\cite{Pari} to compute instances of $G(-e^u)$ at 600 even integers, $u_n\in[6002,\,7200]$, working at 6000-digit precision. This took 30 minutes on a single core. Then~(ef{Ga}) gives sufficient precision to determine, iteratively, 167 rational values of $P_k(0)$ from 600 expansions $S(u_n)\approx\sum_{k\ge0}^{166}P_k(0)/u_n^k$. The iterative process relies on control of the denominator $D_k$ of $P_k(0)=N_k/D_k$. I found that $D_k/D_{k-1}$ is a relatively small rational number, involving no prime greater than $2k+3$. For example $D_{166}/D_{165}=2^3\cdot3^3\cdot5\cdot11\cdot113=1342440$, while $N_{166}$ is 780-digit integer, obtained from numerical data with an absolute error less than $10^{-27}$ and hence with good confidence. Combining this empirical data for $P_k(0)$ with difference polynomials $\Delta_k(x)$, obtained by rational linear algebra from~(ef{dlog}), I determined $P_k(x)$ exactly for $k\in[0,166]$. Studying these results I found that $P_k(x)$ at large $k$ is very well approximated by a sinusoid whose amplitude grows with $k$ exponentially faster than that for $\Delta_k(x)$. Moreover, the phase of this sinusoid for $P_k(x)$ increases linearly with $k$. From~(ef{dlog}), one sees that $g_k=\Delta_k(- rac14)$ has the well-studied generating function~\cite{RA,GN}  egin{equation} \sum_{k\ge0}g_ky^k=\exp\left(\sum_{n>0} rac{B_{2n}\,y^{2n-1}}{2n(2n-1)}ight)= 1+	frac{1}{12}y+	frac{1}{288}y^2-	frac{139}{51840}y^3-	frac{571}{2488320}y^4 +O(y^5).\label{gfun} \end{equation} At large $k$, one has $kg_k=O(k!/(2\pi)^k)$. The detailed behaviour depends on the parity of $k$, with resurgent asymptotic expansions given by  egin{equation} g_{2m}\sim-2\sum_{n=0}^{\lfloor m/2floor} rac{\Gamma(2m-2n-1)g_{2n+1}}{(2\pi{m i})^{2m-2n}},\quad g_{2m-1}\sim-2\sum_{n=0}^{\lfloor m/2floor} rac{\Gamma(2m-2n-1)g_{2n}}{(2\pi{m i})^{2m-2n}}\label{gres} \end{equation} optimally truncated at $n=\lfloor m/2floor$. I found that  egin{equation}\Delta_k(x)= rac{2\,\Gamma(k)}{(2\pi)^{k+1}}\left(\sin\left(4\pi x- rac{k\pi}{2}ight) +O\left( rac{1}{k}ight)ight)\label{Dkasy} \end{equation} for large $k$ and $x\in(-1,\,1)$. At $x=- rac14$, this accords with the leading terms in~(ef{gres}). Solving the difference equation $P_k(x+1)=P_k(x)+\Delta_k(x)$, with the boundary value $P_k(0)$ determined from fits to Hurwitz zeta values, I found a very different sinusoidal pattern for $P_k(x)$ at large $k$. \section{Asymptotic constants} { f Conjecture 1:} {\em For $x\in[0,1)$ and large $k$, there are real constants $(C,R)$ such that}  egin{equation} P_k(x)= rac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\left(\sin((2k+1)C-2\pi x) +O\left( rac{1}{(2\pi R^2)^k}ight)ight)R^{2k+1}\Gamma(k+	frac12).\label{Pkasy} \end{equation} I obtained from $P_k(x)$ with $k\le100$ the approximate values  egin{equation} C\approx1.0688539158679530121571,\quad R\approx0.5181839789815558726739.\label{RC} \end{equation} The correction to the sinusoid in~(ef{Pkasy}) is suppressed by a factor $\exp(-Dk)$, with $D=\log(2\pi R^2)>0.523$, while $C$ determines the rate at which the phase of $P_k(x)$ increases with $k$. The frequency of the sinusoid in the accurate formula for $P_k(x)$ at large $k$ is half the frequency of the rough approximation of $\Delta_k(x)$ in~(ef{Dkasy}). Remarkably, one does not need to evaluate more Hurwitz zeta values to improve the estimates for $C$ and $R$, since the derivatives $P_k^\prime(0)$ and $P_k^{\prime\prime}(0)$ suffice for this purpose. These are determined by $\Delta_k(z)=P_k(x+1)-P_k(x)$, using rational linear algebra. Performing this algebraic task up to $k=450$, I obtained 100 good digits of egin{verbatim} C=1.0688539158679530121571097191811852979525324693901\ 17623122615884099900607451406841033559634662009219352... R=0.5181839789815558726739156977092964730544254253791\ 86245211522277584117542967758199301076306776194323459... \end{verbatim} \section{Discussion and open questions} I have been unable to discover any relation between $C$, $R$, their square roots, powers, logarithms or exponentials, and guesses such as 2, 3, $\pi$, and their square roots, powers, logarithms or exponentials. It might be more appropriate to consider a complex constant, such as $\log(R)+{m i}\,C$, or perhaps $R+{m i}\exp(C)$. Since determination of the derivatives $P_k^\prime(0)$ and $P_k^{\prime\prime}(0)$ from the finite difference equation $P_k(x+1)-P_k(x)=\Delta_k(x)$, at large $k$, is somewhat akin to integration, it might be that $C$ and $R$ are related to the real and imaginary parts of a complex integral, or come from the saddle-point of a complex integrand. It is notable that the overall constant $1/\sqrt{2\pi}$ in~(ef{Pkasy}) is very simple. One often encounters growth of the form $A\,r^k\,\Gamma(k+c)$, where $r$ is easily identified and $c$ is often a simple rational number, yet the overall constant $A$ may be hard to identify, as for example in~\cite{BB}. In the present case I cannot identify $R$, yet can confirm the overall constant $1/\sqrt{2\pi}$, at 100-digit precision. I conclude with several open questions.  egin{enumerate} \item May the rational numbers $P_k(0)$ be determined without recourse to numerical evaluation of Hurwitz zeta values? \item Can formula~(ef{Pkasy}) of Conjecture~1 be proved? \item Might some function of $C$ and/or $R$ be determined precisely? \item Is the sign-constant asymptotic expansion~(ef{Gu}) better handled using directional Borel resummation, as in~\cite{DD}, instead of optimal truncation, as here? \end{enumerate} \section*{Acknowledgments} I am grateful for discussions with David Gross and Gerard {}'t Hooft,
